xxl.core.io.raw
Class RawAccessArrayFilesystemOperations

java.lang.Object
  xxl.core.io.raw.RawAccessArrayFilesystemOperations
All Implemented Interfaces:
FilesystemOperations
public class RawAccessArrayFilesystemOperations
extends Object
implements FilesystemOperations

This class provides a simple filesystem based on an array of RawAccesses. The file system manages a fixed number of files (maximum). The check for equality is case sensitive (like under Linux). Directories are not supported.

initBlocksAtEOF

protected boolean initBlocksAtEOF
Determines iff new space at the end a RandomAccessFile should be initialized will 0-values or not. true is the standard, because it is fully compliant with java.io.RandomAccessFile.

filesCreated

Determines if the files have been created so far.

dummyFile

protected File dummyFile
The implementation needs a file that exists inside the file system. The file is never really used, just opened as read only and immediately closed again. This parameter only exists because of the inflexible implementation of RandomAccessFile.

Constructor Detail

RawAccessArrayFilesystemOperations

public RawAccessArrayFilesystemOperations(RawAccess[] ras,
                                          String[] filenames,
                                          boolean[] filesCreated,
                                          File dummyFile,
                                          boolean initBlocksAtEOF)
Creates a simple file system based on a number of RawAccesses. Initially, the given filenames are mapped to the corresponding RawAccesses. If the corresponding value of filesCreated is true, then it is assumed that the RawAccess already contains data which is the content of the file. If filesCreated is false, then the RawAccess is overwritten.

Parameters:
ras - an array of RawAccesses (@see PartitionRawAccess and @see RawAccessUtils.rawAccessPartitioner)
filenames - names of the files (initially). The length of the array must lower or equal compared to the RawAccess array.
filesCreated - determines if the files have content at the beginning.
dummyFile - The implementation needs a file that exists inside the file system. The file is never really used, just opened as read only and immediately closed again. This parameter only exists because of the inflexible implementation of RandomAccessFile.
initBlocksAtEOF - Determines iff new space at the end a RandomAccessFile should be initialized will 0-values or not. true is the standard, because it is fully compliant with java.io.RandomAccessFile.

RawAccessArrayFilesystemOperations

public RawAccessArrayFilesystemOperations(RawAccess[] ras,
                                          String[] filenames,
                                          boolean filesCreated,
                                          File dummyFile,
                                          boolean initBlocksAtEOF)
Creates a simple file system based on a number of RawAccesses. Initially, the given filenames are mapped to the corresponding RawAccesses. If the value of filesCreated is true, then it is assumed that all RawAccesses already contain data which is the content of the file. If filesCreated is false, then the RawAccesses become overwritten.

Parameters:
ras - an array of RawAccesses (@see PartitionRawAccess and @see RawAccessUtils.rawAccessPartitioner)
filenames - names of the files (initially). The length of the array must lower or equal compared to the RawAccess array.
filesCreated - determines if the files have content at the beginning.
dummyFile - The implementation needs a file that exists inside the file system. The file is never really used, just opened as read only and immediately closed again. This parameter only exists because of the inflexible implementation of RandomAccessFile.
initBlocksAtEOF - Determines iff new space at the end a RandomAccessFile should be initialized will 0-values or not. true is the standard, because it is fully compliant with java.io.RandomAccessFile.

RawAccessArrayFilesystemOperations

public RawAccessArrayFilesystemOperations(RawAccess[] ras,
                                          File dummyFile,
                                          boolean initBlocksAtEOF)
Creates a simple file system based on a number of RawAccesses. Initially, no files exist on the file system.

Parameters:
ras - an array of RawAccesses (@see PartitionRawAccess and @see RawAccessUtils.rawAccessPartitioner)
dummyFile - The implementation needs a file that exists inside the file system. The file is never really used, just opened as read only and immediately closed again. This parameter only exists because of the inflexible implementation of RandomAccessFile.
initBlocksAtEOF - Determines iff new space at the end a RandomAccessFile should be initialized will 0-values or not. true is the standard, because it is fully compliant with java.io.RandomAccessFile.
